data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve list of available VPN servers
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of all available VPN servers. Returns an array of server objects containing server details such as location, status, and connection information. No authentication required for this operation.
data.reasoning: Operation has no summary or description, making it impossible for AI agents to understand its purpose. Added clear action-oriented summary, explanation of what is returned, and authentication requirements.

data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve summary information for all VPN servers

No authentication required.

message: Operation 'Register' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Summary is too generic. Description is verbose and mixes procedural guidance with operational details. Reorganized to clearly separate authentication requirements, inputs, outputs, and side effects. Clarified token lifecycle for AI agent understanding.

data.current_description: This route allows VPN Admin user's with an api key to register a vpn user account. This route can only be called using your api key supplied to you from SimpliVPN. Before calling this you should use your api key to call the /UsernameAvailable route to make sure the username you want is available first. All subsequent user requests following can be done using the user's api token, their token's expire every 7 days, so you should occasionally check them and if you get unauthorized, refresh their token by calling /login route. This route will also auto-enable a new user.
data.summary_suggestion: Register new VPN user account with API key
data.description_suggestion: Registers a new VPN user account. Requires API key authentication. Input: username and password (verify username availability via /username-available endpoint first). Returns user object with authentication token valid for 7 days. Side effects: automatically enables VPN access for the new user. Subsequent user operations use the returned token; refresh via /login when token expires.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic. Description is verbose and mixes procedural guidance with operational details. Reorganized to clearly separate authentication requirements, inputs, outputs, and side effects. Clarified token lifecycle for AI agent understanding.

message: Operation 'Login' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Summary is too generic. Description lacks clarity on inputs, has typo ('rquests'), and doesn't clearly explain token refresh behavior. Improved summary with action-oriented language, specified inputs/outputs, clarified token lifecycle, and added side effect information for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: This route allows you to login a user. The response will give you a Bearer auth token to use with all rquests pertaining to the user. This token expires in 7 days, so for every request you should check if you get an unauthorized responsve and re-validate the login if needed.
data.summary_suggestion: Authenticate user and obtain Bearer token
data.description_suggestion: Authenticates a user and returns a Bearer authentication token for subsequent API requests. Input: username and password. Returns user object with Bearer token valid for 7 days. Token expires after 7 days; when requests return 401 Unauthorized, call this endpoint again to refresh the token. Side effect: invalidates any previously issued tokens for the user.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic. Description lacks clarity on inputs, has typo ('rquests'), and doesn't clearly explain token refresh behavior. Improved summary with action-oriented language, specified inputs/outputs, clarified token lifecycle, and added side effect information for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: This route allows you to enable a user's vpn access. This route can only be called using your user's Bearer Auth token.
data.description_suggestion: Enables VPN access for a user account. Requires Bearer token authentication. Input: user identifier (from request schema). Returns confirmation of enabled status. Side effect: user can now establish VPN connections. Use this to restore access for previously disabled accounts.
data.reasoning: Summary uses PascalCase which is inconsistent with domain terminology. Description lacks input/output details and doesn't explain when this operation should be used. Improved summary with domain-appropriate terminology, added context about inputs/outputs, and clarified use case for AI agents.

data.current_description: This route allows you to disable a user's vpn access.
data.description_suggestion: Disables VPN access for a user account, preventing new connections. Requires Bearer token authentication. Input: user identifier (from request schema). Returns confirmation of disabled status. Side effects: user cannot establish new VPN connections; existing connections may be terminated. Use to revoke access or enforce account restrictions.
data.reasoning: Summary uses PascalCase inconsistent with domain terminology. Description is extremely vague with no input/output/side effect details. data.current_description: This route allows VPN Admin user's to check if a specific username is available before registering an account username. This route can only be called using your api key supplied to you from SimpliVPN.
data.summary_suggestion: Check if username is available for registration
data.description_suggestion: Checks whether a username is available for new VPN account registration. Requires API key authentication. Input: username string to validate. Returns boolean indicating availability (true if available, false if taken). Use this endpoint before calling /register to ensure the desired username can be registered.
data.reasoning: Summary uses PascalCase inconsistent with domain terminology. Description lacks clarity on inputs and outputs. Improved summary with action-oriented language, specified input/output format clearly, added authentication requirement, and provided context for when to use this operation in relation to /register.
